Comment: You can simplistically divide politicians into populists and machine politicians. The latter spend their time appealing to their peers within the party to get enough support to take 'their turn'. Of post-war American Presidents, you'd probably classify Truman, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Bush I/II, Clinton and Biden this way. While they obviously have to be popular enough with the voters to get elected, their policies and rhetoric are aimed at a narrow class of elites who occupy positions of power in the party.  In contrast, populists attempt to circumvent the party hierarchy by appealing directly to the public. Eisenhower, JFK, Carter, Obama and Trump would all likely fall into this category. Because they're focused on the rank-and-file voter, they tend to generate a lot more enthusiasm from those voters. However, they tend to have difficulty building a durable legacy because they don't have the party hierarchy behind them.
